text: this is Henry fountain for the New York
Times there's still a lot that
scientists don't know about tornadoes
but here's some of what they do know the
tornado and more was rated a 5 at the
top of the Enhanced Fujita scale
planning the tornado was initially rated
a for but analysts determined that the
damage to homes commercial buildings and
trees was caused by wind speeds over 200
miles an hour making it a category 5
factors like population density play a
role in how deadly a tornado will become
the last time we saw a category 5
tornado was in 2011 it tore through the
city of Joplin Missouri and killed over
a hundred and fifty people while
scientists are able to predict with some
precision the track and timing of a
hurricane tornadoes cover a smaller area
and can appear in a matter of minutes
that can give little warning for
residents to find appropriate shelter on
Monday residents of Moore Oklahoma were
told that severe weather was coming but
they didn't get an actual tornado
warning until 15 minutes before it hit
while the tornado and more was deadly it
comes in the middle of a tornado season
that until now had been relatively quiet
warm moist air is a key ingredient in
cooking up a tornado but earlier this
year the high-altitude winds of the jet
stream brought cold air to the Midwest
keeping warmer air out it's the same
wind pattern that made for a cold spring
in the Northeast
now as temperatures continue to rise
across the country there's no way to
know whether the Midwest has seen the
worst of extreme weather
you
